moves.1. b4: it turns out that from whites 20 possible opening moves, b4 ranks ninth in popularity... it boggles my mind why on earth...
moves.1... d5 2. Bb2 Nf6 3. e3 e5 4. Bxe5 Bxb4: not very much ado here... apart from the fact, that black is in control now; in stead of white...
moves.13. g3: understandable, but inaccurate; best is Re1, Ne4, Ne5, etctera, to release all tensions...
moves.13... Bg4 14. Be2 Na5 15. Nh4: maybe better Nd2, c6, Re1, Bxe2...
moves.15... Bxe2 16. Qxe2 Qxe2 17. Nxe2 Nc4 18: Rfb1 (Rab1?, Nd2), b5, Bc1 is slightly better...
moves.18... c6 19. c3 a5 20. Ng2 a4 21. Ne1 Ne: probably the losing inaccuracy of them all... Rxa3, Rxb4, or Nc6(!), bxc6, Rxa3, Rb1+, were much to be preferred...
moves.33... h5 34. Nc2: much tougher is Na2, hxg4, Rc8+...
moves.34... Rc7 35. g5 e3 36. Re2 Rb2 37. d5 R: no difference makes Rexc2, Nxc2, d6, Nd4!, Rf1, Rf2, Rxf2, exf2+, Kxf2, a3!, d7, Nc6...
moves.38... Nxc2 39. d6 Kf8: white resigns... blacks' a-pawn can no longer be stopped, and the e-pawn is invulnerable... d7, is easily met with Ke7; the white rook is trapped...
